case_name: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Board v. Mahant

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 407 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 407 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal arises from judgment and decree dated March 13, 1962 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No 330 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 13, 1962 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No 3 30 of 1958.

facts.text: Dispute between appellant-Board and respondent over enforcement of Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1 of 1951 on Kamlabari asthal estate consisting of temple, buildings and lands.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from a dispute between the appellant-Board and the respondent which occurred when the Board tried to enforce the provisions of the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1 of 1951, in respect of the estate known as Kamlabari asthal companysisting of a temple, buildings and lands.

facts.text: Respondent is the current mahant claiming direct descent from founding mahant Gaibi Ramdasji in guru to chela succession.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the current mahant claiming direct descent from the founding mahant Gaibi Ramdasji in the line of succession from Guru to Chela.

facts.text: Gaibi Ramdasji received lands from Maharaja of Darbhanga and other zamindars.

anchor.surface_text: Gaibi Ramdasji was the recipient of certain lands from the then Maharaja of Darbhanga and other zamindars.

facts.text: Temple with Shri Ram, Janki and Laxmanji as presiding deities and residential buildings were constructed from income of these lands.

anchor.surface_text: From out of the income of these lands, a temple with Shri Ram, janki and Laxmanji as the presiding deities thereof, and certain residential buildings were companystructed.

facts.text: Later mahants added properties by acquisition from income of existing properties.

anchor.surface_text: Later mahants added to these properties by acquisition from out of the income of the existing properties.

facts.text: Board demanded production of accounts and particulars from respondent mahant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent mahant resisted the Boards demand for production of accounts and other particulars

facts.text: Board initiated criminal proceedings against respondent mahant.

anchor.surface_text: and in companysequence the Board took out criminal proceedings against the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit claiming asthal and properties as personal properties, not religious trusts under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed a suit of which this appeal is the outcome. In the suit, the respondent claimed that the said asthal and its properties were his personal properties, the gifts of lands having originally been made personally to the founding mahant

facts.text: Board claimed properties are not personal but belong to asthal, public interest shown by public darshan, festivals, offerings, feeding sadhus.

anchor.surface_text: The Board took the stand that the asthal and the properties belonging to it were number the personal properties of the manant or his predecessors, that the, gifts to them were number personal gifts but to the asthal that the fact that members of the public had, without any let or hindrance, been using the temple for darshan and worship, the fact that festivals were celebrated at which members of the public gave offerings, the practice of feeding of sadhus and pilgrims, all went to indicate that the asthal was a public trust

facts.text: Both parties led considerable oral and documentary evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Both sides led companysiderable amount of evidence, both oral and documentary.

facts.text: Oral evidence included witnesses testifying to public access to temple without obstruction and some turned away.

anchor.surface_text: The oral evidence companysisted of the testimony of witnesses, some of whom deposed, on the one hand, that the members of the , public had been companying to the temple without any obstruction on the part of the mahant, and some others, on the other hand, that on certain occasions some of the members of the public had actually been turned away from the temple.

facts.text: Respondent did not produce sanads of founding mahant acquisitions, claimed could not be traced.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the documentary evidence, the respondent mahant did number produce the sanads under which the founding mahant had acquired properties. These, he said, companyld number be traced.

facts.text: Board did not produce Darbhanga Estate records.

anchor.surface_text: The Board also did number make any attempt to produce the record of the Darbhanga Estate which, on merger there-of with the State of Bihar presumably must be in the custody of the State Government.

facts.text: Trial Judge held asthal and properties are public religious trust under Act 1 of 1951, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence before him he ultimately hold that the asthal and the properties appertaining thereto were public religious trust and dismissed the respondents suit.

facts.text: Patna High Court reversed Trial Court, held properties not subject to Act as not public trust.

anchor.surface_text: On this view the High Court reversed the judgment of the Trial Judge and decreed the respondents suit, holding that the Act did number apply to the properties in suit.

facts.text: Succession to mahantship always from guru to chela, no public voice in selection.

anchor.surface_text: that he was succeeded to the mahantship by his chela, and thereafter succession to the mahantship had been from guru to chela, 3.that the appointment of a successor has been all throughout from guru to chela, the reigning mahant appointing or numberinating his successor from amongst his chelas and the members of the public have had at numbertime any voice in the selection or numberination

facts.text: Properties always recorded in names of mahants as proprietors, not deities.

anchor.surface_text: that the properties have always, been recorded in the names of the mahants as proprietors and number in the name of the deities in the D registers, khewats and khatians

facts.text: Mahants in possession and management of asthal and properties throughout.

anchor.surface_text: that the mahants have been in possession and management of the, asthal and the properties all throughout

facts.text: Mahants acquired properties in own names, dealt via sales, mortgages etc without objection.

anchor.surface_text: that the mahants acquired properties from time to time in their own names as proprietors and-never in the names of the deities 6r the asthal, without, any objection at any time from any one and dealt with, some of them through deeds of sales, mortgages, leases etc.

facts.text: Mahants were bairagis, celibates.

anchor.surface_text: the fact that the mahants were vaishnav bairagis who were life long celibates

facts.text: Sadhus, pilgrims fed and sheltered at temple.

anchor.surface_text: that sadhus and others were given food and shelter when they visited the temple

facts.text: Festivals celebrated with public attendance and offerings.

anchor.surface_text: that festivals and other important Hindu dates used to be celebrated

facts.text: Supreme Court held onus on Board to prove public trust, Trial Court erred in adverse inference from non-production of sanads.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge was, therefore, clearly in error in holding that the respondent-mahant ought to have produced the sanads and that on his failure to do so an adverse inference companyld be drawn

religious trusts as defined by S. 2 1  of the Act. That sub-section defines a religious trust to mean any express or constructive trust created or existing for any pur- pose recognised by Hindu Law to be religious, pious or charitable but shall number include a trust created according to Sikh religion or purely for the benefit of the Sikh companymunity and a private endowment created for the worship of the family idol in which the public are number interested.

concepts.interpretation: Definition excludes private endowments where public not interested; only public religious trusts covered, as clarified in Mahant Ramsaroop Das ji v. S. P. Sahi

issues.text: Whether the temple and the properties in suit are the personal properties of the plaintiff or are trust properties under the provisions of Act 1 of 1951 ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the temple and the properties in suit are the personal properties of the plaintiff or are trust properties under the provisions of Act 1 of 1951 ?

issues.text: Whether the properties are held by the respondent-mahant on trust for public purposes of a religious or charitable character

anchor.surface_text: Properties of the temple being thus admittedly in the possession of the mahants ever since the time of Gaibi Ramdasji, the onus of proof that the respondent-mahant held them on trust for public purposes of a religious or charitable character was clearly on the appellant-Board

issues.text: Whether an adverse inference could be drawn from the failure of the respondent-mahant to produce the sanads

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge was, therefore, clearly in error in holding that the respondent-mahant ought to have produced the sanads and that on his failure to do so an adverse inference could be drawn

issues.text: Whether the circumstances such as celibacy of mahants, feeding of sadhus, celebration of festivals, public access to temple, and description in deeds indicate a public religious trust
Whether the asthal is a public mutt or a private mutt
Whether the expression 'properties appertaining to the asthal' in deeds indicates a public trust

arguments.claim: The asthal and its properties were the personal properties of the respondent mahant, as gifts were made personally to the founding mahant and succeeding mahants, not religious trusts under S.2(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed a suit of which this appeal is the outcome. In the suit, the respondent claimed that the said asthal and its properties were his personal properties, the gifts of lands having originally been made personally to the founding mahant

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is alleged that such property is a trust property held for public purposes to which Acts, such as the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920 or th

arguments.court_reasoning: Onus on Board to prove public trust; properties in mahants' possession; consistent with private religious endowment, not personal secular

arguments.claim: The asthal and properties are not personal but belong to the asthal as public trust, evidenced by public darshan without hindrance, festivals with offerings, feeding sadhus and pilgrims

anchor.surface_text: The Board took the stand that the asthal and the properties belonging to it were not the personal properties of the mahant or his predecessors, that the gifts to them were not personal gifts but to the asthal that the fact that members of the public had, without any let or hindrance, been using the temple for darshan and worship, the fact that festivals were celebrated at which members of the public gave offerings, the practice of feeding of sadhus and pilgrims, all went to indicate that the asthal was a public trust

arguments.court_reasoning: Public user, feeding sadhus, festivals consistent with private temples; not sufficient proof of dedication to public; precedents Parmanand, Babu Bhagwan Din

arguments.claim: The properties are public religious trusts under the Act, as Trial Judge held based on evidence

anchor.surface_text: On the evidence before him he ultimately held that the asthal and the properties appertaining thereto were public religious trust and dismissed the respondents suit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: that the evidence on record had to be viewed in the light of the definition section as companystructed by this Court in Mahant Ramsaroopdasji v. Sahi

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court reversed; SC agrees Act does not apply as not public trust; Trial erred on onus and inferences

arguments.claim: Mahants being bairagis/celibates raises presumption they held properties for asthal

anchor.surface_text: In coming to this conclusion the Trial Judge took into account the following circumstances 1 that the mahants were bairagis, i.e., celibates, which fact raised the presumption that they held properties on behalf of the asthal to which their lives were entirely devoted

arguments.court_reasoning: Parmanand v Nihal Chand: celibacy and guru-chela descent not indicative of religious/public properties

arguments.claim: Mahant Gaibi Ramdasji set up sampradaya attracting followers; temple for benefit of followers and propagating doctrines, presuming dedication to public/section

anchor.surface_text: 2 that Mahant Gaibi Ramdasji had set up a sampradaya which attracted a large following, that therefore, the temple built by him was for the benefit of his followers and for spreading and propagating the doctrines of that sampradaya, 3 that from these facts the presumption arose that he had dedicated the temple and the properties to the public or a section thereof

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence of public dedication; private mutt possible for spiritual family/lineage

arguments.claim: Evidence of entertaining sadhus/fakirs/abhyagats, spending on puja/religious activities/festivals presumes properties subject to religious/charitable purposes

anchor.surface_text: 4 that the evidence showed that sadhus, fakirs and abhyagats were entertained at the temple, that the income of the properties was spent on puja and other religious activities and for festivals consequently, the presumption was that the properties were subject to religious and charitable purposes

arguments.court_reasoning: Feeding sadhus/wayfarers part of private worship duties; festivals in private temples too; not public trust

arguments.claim: Pran Pratishtha and ceremonies at installation dedicate temple/properties to public

anchor.surface_text: 5 that at the time of the installation of the deities in the temple Pran Pratishtha and other ceremonies must have been performed which meant that the temple and the properties were declared to have been dedicated to the public

arguments.court_reasoning: No clear evidence of Pratistha/Utsarga; general statement insufficient; found in private temples too

arguments.claim: Deeds describe mahants as asthaldharis, properties appertaining to asthal

anchor.surface_text: 6 that the deeds of appointment of successors executed by the mahants described the mahants as asthaldharis and the properties as appertaining to the asthal, and 7 that though revenue records described the mahants as proprietors of these properties, they had to be read in the light of the facts aforestated.

arguments.court_reasoning: Expression 'appertaining to asthal' means part of asthal, but asthal not proven public trust

arguments.claim: Even if not private personal properties, factors consistent only with private religious trust, not public; Act does not apply

anchor.surface_text: On this view the High Court reversed the judgment of the Trial Judge and decreed the respondents suit, holding that the Act did not apply to the properties in suit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is alleged that such property is a trust property held for public purposes to which Acts, such as the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920 or th

arguments.claim: Celibacy of mahants, feeding sadhus/shelter, festivals, public darshan as of right, deeds describing properties appertaining to asthal prove public trust

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances and the conduct relied on were 1 the fact that the mahants were vaishnav bairagis who were life long celibates 2 that sadhus and others were given food and shelter when they visited the temple 3 that festivals and other important Hindu dates used to be celebrated 4 that the members of the public came to the temple for darshan without any hindrance and as of right 5 that in the deeds and wills, whereby reigning mahants appointed or nominated their successors, the properties were described as appertaining to the asthal

arguments.court_reasoning: Not indicative per precedents; consistent with private

arguments.court_reasoning: Asthal not proven public; expression means appurtenant but requires asthal to be public trust

arguments.claim: Act applies only to public trusts, not private per Ramsaroop Dasji

anchor.surface_text: Whether the temple and the properties in suit are the personal properties of the plaintiff or are trust properties under the provisions of Act 1 of 1951 ? ... Sahi the correct position is that private trusts do not fall within the ambit of the definition in that section.

arguments.claim: Onus on Board to prove public religious/charitable trust given mahants' possession

anchor.surface_text: Properties of the temple being thus admittedly in the possession of the mahants ever since the time of Gaibi Ramdasji, the onus of proof that the respondent-mahant held them on trust for public purposes of a religious or charitable character was clearly on the appellant-Board

arguments.claim: No adverse inference from non-production of sanads as unavailable to both parties

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge was, therefore, clearly in error in holding that the respondent-mahant ought to have produced the sanads and that on his failure to do so an adverse inference could be drawn

arguments.claim: Celibacy/guru-chela not presumption of public trust (Parmanand v Nihal Chand)
Public user/darshan, offerings, festivals, mela not dedication to public (Babu Bhagwan Din)
Private mutts/asthals possible, not necessarily public; depends on intention/beneficiaries
Puran Atal case distinguished: no similar evidence of user/declarations here

holdings.text: Private trusts do not fall within the ambit of the definition of 'religious trust' in S.2(1) of the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the temple and the properties in suit are the personal properties of the plaintiff or are trust properties under the provisions of Act 1 of 1951 ? ... That decision was however, reversed on appeal to this Court and as reported in Mahant Ramsaroop Das ji v. S. P. Sahi the correct position is that private trusts do not fall within the ambit of the definition in that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Mahant Ramsaroop Das ji v. S. P. Sahi which reversed High Court interpretation, Act covers only public trusts excluding private endowments for family idol worship.

holdings.text: Onus of proof that properties are held on trust for public religious or charitable purposes lies on the party alleging it (Board), when properties admittedly in possession of mahants.

anchor.surface_text: Properties of the temple being thus admittedly in the possession of the mahants ever since the time of Gaibi Ramdasji, the onus of proof that the respondent-mahant held them on trust for public purposes of a religious or charitable character was clearly on the appellant-Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted possession by mahants shifts burden to claimant of public character; Trial Court erred in placing onus on respondent.

holdings.text: No adverse inference can be drawn from respondent-mahant's failure to produce sanads, as they were unavailable to both parties.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge was, therefore, clearly in error in holding that the respondent-mahant ought to have produced the sanads and that on his failure to do so an adverse inference could be drawn

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board also failed to produce relevant records like Darbhanga Estate; documents not exclusively in respondent's custody.

holdings.text: Circumstances like celibacy of mahants, feeding sadhus, festivals, public darshan do not prove dedication to public trust.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Factors consistent with private religious endowments; precedents Parmanand v. Nihal Chand, Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroop hold no presumption from such user.

holdings.text: The asthal is a private mutt, not public, as no intention to benefit public or unascertained class proven.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Private mutts exist for spiritual family/lineage; no evidence of public dedication unlike public mutts for ascetics generally; distinguishes Puran Atal.

holdings.text: Expression 'properties appertaining to the asthal' does not indicate public trust unless asthal itself is public trust.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Means appurtenant to asthal; requires prior finding asthal public; cites Sri Thakurji Ramji v. Mathura Prasad.

holdings.text: Mere fact of mahants being celibates (bairagis) and guru-chela succession does not raise presumption of public religious properties.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applying Privy Council precedent in Parmanand v. Nihal Chand; secular properties can descend similarly.

holdings.text: Dedication to public not readily inferred from public user (darshan, offerings, festivals, mela) when property granted to individual/family.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Hazardous inference per Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroop; consistent with private temples, Hindu sentiments against turning worshippers.

holdings.text: Feeding sadhus, pilgrims, wayfarers does not convert private idol worship trust into public trust.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Part of due worship/seva puja in private debutter; cites Ramsaran Das v. Jai Ram Das.
